get.summary: Gets the configuration of the mail filter backend.
get.description:
A mail filter can have different rules each containing one command. A command has a test condition and actions
that are executed if the condition is true. The list of available comparisions (that can be used in test
conditions) and the list of available actions depends on a given test and the mail filter server configuration
and must be determined at runtime.

All those dynamic values can be fetched via a config object at startup, which shows the capabilities of the server
to the client.

parameters.name: username
parameters.description: Must contain the user name for **admin mode**. So the normal credentials are taken for authentication but the mail filter of the user with this username is being changed.

200.description:
A JSON object with the fields `tests` (containing an array of available test-objects, see [Possible tests](#possible-tests).) and `actioncommands`
(containing an array of valid actions. See [Possible action commands](#possible-action-commands)). In case of errors the responsible fields in the response are
filled (see [Error handling](#error-handling)).

parameters.name: flag
parameters.description: If given, only rules with this flag are returned.

parameters.name: username
parameters.description: Must contain the user name for **admin mode**. So the normal credentials are taken for authentication but the mail filter of the user with this username is being changed.

200.description:
A JSON object with an array of rule-objects. In case of errors the responsible fields in the response are
filled (see [Error handling](#error-handling)).

parameters.name: username
parameters.description: Must contain the user name for **admin mode**. So the normal credentials are taken for authentication but the mail filter of the user with this username is being changed.

parameters.name: body
parameters.description: A JSON object describing the mail filter rule. If the field `position` is included, it's taken as the position of the rule in the array on the server side (this value shouldn't be greater than the size of all rules).

200.description:
A JSON object containing the ID of the newly created rule. In case of errors the responsible fields in the response are
filled (see [Error handling](#error-handling)).

parameters.name: username
parameters.description: Must contain the user name for **admin mode**. So the normal credentials are taken for authentication but the mail filter of the user with this username is being changed.

parameters.name: body
parameters.description: A JSON object with the ID of the rule to delete.

200.description: In case of errors the responsible fields in the response are filled (see [Error handling](#error-handling)).

parameters.name: username
parameters.description: Must contain the user name for **admin mode**. So the normal credentials are taken for authentication but the mail filter of the user with this username is being changed.

parameters.name: body
parameters.description: A JSON array with unique identifiers, which represents how the corresponding rules are order.

200.description: In case of errors the responsible fields in the response are filled (see [Error handling](#error-handling)).

parameters.name: username
parameters.description: Must contain the user name for **admin mode**. So the normal credentials are taken for authentication but the mail filter of the user with this username is being changed.

parameters.name: body
parameters.description: A JSON object describing the rule with the `id` set (which identifies the rule to change). Only modified fields are present.

200.description: In case of errors the responsible fields in the response are filled (see [Error handling](#error-handling)).

get.description:
A messaging message consists of some metadata, headers and a content. The content attribute varies
by the content-type header. If the content-type is `text/*` it is a string, if it is `multipart/*` it
is an array of objects, each representing a part of the multipart. If it is anything else it is considered binary
and is a Base64 encoded string.

The folder ID of a message follows a predefined format: `[messagingService]://[accountId]/[path]`, like
`com.openexchange.messaging.twitter://535/defaultTimeline/directMessages`.

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: The ID of the message to load.

parameters.name: folder
parameters.description: The folder ID of the message.

parameters.name: peek
parameters.description: If set to `true` the read/unread state of the message will not change. Default is `false`.

200.description:
A JSON object containing the data of the message. In case of errors the responsible fields in the
response are filled (see [Error handling](#error-handling)).

parameters.name: recipients
parameters.description: A list of recipients as defined in [RFC822](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc822), like "Joe Doe <joe@doe.org>". If set the message is sent to the given list of recipients, otherwise this defaults to the "To" header of the message.

parameters.name: body
parameters.description: A JSON array of JSON arrays with the folder and ID as elements each identifying a message.

200.description:
A JSON object containing the number 1 if message could be sent. In case of errors the responsible fields in the
response are filled (see [Error handling](#error-handling).

put.description:
On actions of type "message" the body should contain the JSON representation of the message the action should be applied to.
To invoke a messaging action of type "storage" the folder and id are needed in URL parameters.
Messaging actions of type "none" need a messaging message and account.

parameters.name: id

parameters.name: account

parameters.name: body

200.description:
A JSON object containing the number 1 if message could be sent. In case of errors the responsible fields in the
response are filled (see [Error handling](#error-handling)).

put.summary: Processes multiple requests to other modules in a single request.
put.description:
#### Not supported requests are:
 * the ones from modules login and multiple
 * POST requests with a multipart encoding (uploads)
 * GET requests which do not use an object as described in [Low level protocol](#low-level-protocol)

#### Request body
A JSON array with JSON objects describing the requests. Each object contains a field `module` with the
name of the request's module and the field `action` with the concrete request action to execute. Additionally the
parameters of the request are added as fields too. A session parameter is not included! If the request has
a request body itself, this body is stored as a JSON object in a field `data`.

#### Example: query reminder range and update a reminder's alarm
```json
[{"module":"reminder","action":"range","end":1497461067180},{"module":"reminder","action":"remindAgain","id":51,"data":{"alarm":1459478800000}}]
```

parameters.name: continue
parameters.description: Specifies whether processing of requests should stop when an error occurs, or whether all request should be processed regardless of errors.

parameters.name: body
parameters.description: A JSON array with JSON objects, each describing one request.

200.description: A JSON array containing the response data of the processed requests where response[0] corresponds to request[0], response[1] to request[1], and so on.

400.description: Syntactically incorrect request.

get.summary: Initiate the communication with the OpenID module
get.description:
The init request is used to initiate communication with the OpenID module from a UI client.
It may be used to login or logout a user or to initiate the authorization process from  a third party.

parameters.name: flow
parameters.description:
One of the three following strings can be used, {login, logout, thirdParty}. Either one 
will start the corresponding process in the OpenID module.

parameters.name: redirect
parameters.description:
Describes wether the response will be in form of a redirect or an URL placed in a 'redirect' parameter 
in a JSON body.

parameters.name: hash
parameters.description: The hash value from where the request was triggered for later deeplink purposes.

parameters.name: client
parameters.description: The client identifier.

parameters.name: version
parameters.description: The client version.

200.description: A JSON object containing the redirect URL in an own 'redirect' parameter.

302.description: A redirect to the OpenID provider for user authentication.

post.description: The init request as a POST is for thirdParty flow only. Will directly inititate the login process.

parameters.name: redirect
parameters.description:
Describes wether the response will be in form of a redirect or an URL placed in a 'redirect' parameter 
in a JSON body.

parameters.name: hash

parameters.name: client

parameters.name: version
parameters.description: The client version.

200.description: A JSON object containing the redirect URL in an own 'redirect' parameter.

302.description: A redirect to the OpenID provider for user authentication.

If `module` is not specified it is returned a JSON object containing all quota modules as fields.
Each field is an object itself consisting of a field `display_name` and a field `accounts`.
`accounts` is an array of JSON objects containing the properties `account_id`, `account_name`,
`countquota` (account's quota limit for the number of items, or not set if not defined),
`countuse` (account's actual usage for the number of items, or not set if no count quota defined),
`quota` (account's quota limit for the storage in bytes, or not set if not defined) and `use`
(account's actual usage for the storage in bytes, or not set if no storage quota defined). In case of errors the responsible
fields in the response are filled (see [Error handling](#error-handling)).

400.description: If a specified `module` is not existing.

fields in the response are filled (see [Error handling](#error-handling)).

get.description:
Initiates any supported SAML 2.0 login and logout flow as described
in https://documentation.open-xchange.com/latest/middleware/login/02_saml.html.

parameters.name: tenant
parameters.description:
In a multi-tenant environment, where different tenants might
connect to different identity providers, this parameter denotes
the tenant to start a SAML flow for. In single-tenant environments
this parameter is superfluous.

parameters.name: flow
parameters.description: One of `login`, `relogin` or `logout` to start the respective flow.

parameters.name: session
parameters.description: Required for flow `logout`. A session ID to determine the correct session.

parameters.name: redirect
parameters.description:
Responds with `302 Found` and sets the response header `Location`
to the actual redirect URI.

200.description:
Request was successful. Response JSON contains a redirect URI that
the client must follow to continue.

redirect_uri.description: A redirect URI that the client must follow to continue

302.description: In case a redirect was requested

Location.description: A redirect URI that the client must follow to continue

400.description: In case of missing or invalid query parameters

500.description: In case of an internal server error

get.summary: Create App Suite session after SAML login flow
get.description:
This API call is typically the result of a redirect created by the server. It does not
need to be explicitly implemented by clients!

After a successful SAML login flow, the client (web browser) is redirected
to this endpoint, where the actual App Suite session gets created. As a result,
the user gets redirected to `https://<webmail-domain>/<login-path>#session=<session-id>`.
The redirect response has App Suite session cookies set.

parameters.name: token
parameters.description: A valid session reservation token

parameters.name: client
parameters.description:
Identifier of the client using the HTTP/JSON interface.
Default: Value of configuration property `com.openexchange.ajax.login.http-auth.client`

parameters.name: clientUserAgent
parameters.description: Parameter to override the user agent used for session creation. By default the `User-Agent` request header is evaluated.

parameters.name: loginPath
parameters.description:
The login path to be set on the resulting `Location` response header as part of the redirect response.
Default: Value of configuration property `com.openexchange.UIWebPath`.

parameters.name: shard
parameters.description: Shard identifier to route the requiest accordingly

200.description: A html error page

302.description: In case of a succes the middleware answers with a redirect to for bootstrapping the client session

Location.description: A redirect URI that the client must follow to continue

400.description: In case the token is missing

403.description: In case the login is not allowed

get.summary: Terminates an App Suite session after SAML logout flow
get.description:
This API call is typically the result of a redirect created by the server. It does not
need to be explicitly implemented by clients!

After a successful SAML logout flow, the client (web browser) is redirected
to this endpoint, where the actual App Suite session gets terminated. As a result,
the user gets usually redirected to an environment-specific location, for example
a portal page. The redirect response removes all App Suite session cookies.

parameters.name: session
parameters.description: App Suite session ID

200.description: A html result page

302.description: A redirect to an exit page

Location.description: A redirect URI that the client must follow to continue

post.summary: Assertion Consumer Service
post.description:
SAML 2.0 Assertion Consumer Service. Accepts `<Response>` messages of the
Web Browser SSO Profile per `HTTP-POST` binding.

parameters.name: tenant
parameters.description:
In a multi-tenant environment, where different tenants might
connect to different identity providers, this parameter denotes
the tenant to start a SAML flow for. In single-tenant environments
this parameter is superfluous.

parameters.name: SAMLResponse
parameters.description: Base64 encoded SAML 2.0 `<Response>` message.

parameters.name: RelayState
parameters.description: Message exchange relay state. Optional on unsolicited responses.

Location.description: A redirect URI that the client must follow to continue

default.description: Environment specific exit path (HTML page or redirect) on any error

get.summary: Single Logout Service for Logout Requests
get.description:
SAML 2.0 Single Logout Service. Accepts `<LogoutRequest>` messages from the IdP
per `HTTP-Redirect` binding.

parameters.name: tenant
parameters.description:
In a multi-tenant environment, where different tenants might
connect to different identity providers, this parameter denotes
the tenant to start a SAML flow for. In single-tenant environments
this parameter is superfluous.

parameters.name: SAMLRequest
parameters.description: Base64 encoded SAML 2.0 `<LogoutRequest>` message.

parameters.name: SigAlg
parameters.description: Message signature algorithm ID

parameters.name: Signature
parameters.description: Message signature

parameters.name: RelayState
parameters.description: Message exchange relay state

200.description:
HTML response with a self-submitting from that POSTs the `<LoginResponse>`
back to the IdP.

302.description:
Redirect URI that submits the `<LoginResponse>` back to the IdP per
`HTTP-Redirect` binding.

Location.description: A redirect URI that the client must follow to continue

400.description: In case of a missing `SAMLRequest` parameter

500.description: In case of internal server errors

post.summary: Single Logout Service for Logout Responses
post.description:

Single Logout Profile per `HTTP-POST` binding.

the tenant to start a SAML flow for. In single-tenant environments
this parameter is superfluous.

parameters.name: SAMLResponse
parameters.description: Base64 encoded SAML 2.0 `<LogoutResponse>` message.

parameters.name: RelayState
parameters.description: Message exchange relay state

Location.description: A redirect URI that the client must follow to continue

default.description: Environment specific exit path (HTML page or redirect) on any error
